Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Ecology in Context: Research Strategies and Applications for the Undergraduate
Award.AbstractNarration: The Institute of Ecosystem Studies (IES) will offer an undergraduate research opportunity through the Ecology in Context program. Ten students will be selected to join the unique IES research community to carry out cutting-edge investigations of their own design, working closely with a mentor scientist. The program emphasizes the community nature of the scientific enterprise. As participants design and complete their independent research projects they consult with other scientists, present their plans for critique, and then speak in the annual Undergraduate Research Symposium and write a paper for the peer-reviewed on-line IES Occasional Publication. The program provides students many opportunities to reflect upon and think about the process of science and its place in the world, and to develop their skills in doing science. Through a case study of a regional environmental issue, a career forum, and a day spent teaching high school students from a nearby city; students explore the social, political, intellectual and personal dimensions of being an ecologist. The twelve-week program is open to undergraduate freshmen, sophomores, juniors or first semester seniors. Applicants must be citizens or permanent residents of the U.S. or its possessions. Participants receive a stipend, a meal allowance, free housing, and assistance with travel to and from the program. More information is available at http://www.ecostudies.org/reu.html, or by contacting Heather L. Dahl (Coordinator) at (845) 677-7600 x326 or dahlh@ecostudies.org.

Cary Institute - 2006-2010 REU Program Outcomes Report

The Cary Institute of Ecosystem Studies has offered its Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program to 8-12 students every summer since 1988. The 2006-2010 program (Ecology in Context: Research Strategies and Applications for the Undergraduate) was directed by Alan R. Berkowitz, Richard S. Ostfeld, Stuart E.G. Findlay and Felicia Keesing with 24 mentors and 54 students participating. The intensive 12 week summer program immersed them in the highly interactive research environment. Working closely with mentor scientists (Figure 1), students delineated a question, developed and implemented projects, analyzed data, gave an oral presentation in a formal symposium. Students were given many opportunities to reflect on what it means to be a scientist, and to learn about where science in general and ecology in particular fit into broader contexts through enrichment activities. These included discussions, seminars, field trips (Figure 2), a case study, the Sharing Science program (Figure 3), and a full-day Forum on Opportunities in Ecology (Figure 4).

Intellectual Merit

The program contributed to the field of ecology, with 65 peer reviewed publications over 26 years (9 in 2006-2010 plus 40 (74%) final papers for the Undergraduate Research Reports (http://www.caryinstitute.org/publications/307)). Students helped mentors explore new avenues or develop new methodologies. As one mentor stated, the [Cary] REU program has been enormously beneficial to my research program largely by allowing me to help students devise projects that also constitute pilot projects for me...in addition, it creates an atmosphere of education/collaboration with undergraduates that I find extremely useful.

 

Exemplary projects show the diversity, depth and excitement of the contributions to ecology:

  • Dustin Kincaid (2006) worked with Stuart Findlay on the emerging problem of salt pollution in streams, resulting in a high profile article in Water, Air, & Soil Pollution.
  • David Seekell (2007), working with Michael Pace, described long term warming trends in water temperatures in the Hudson River and produced important publications in the Journal of Environmental Monitoring and Currents. 
  • Jessica Vitale (2008) worked with William Schlesinger to analyze local data on spring arrival of song birds and published in the Northeastern Naturalist.
  • Jacob Malcomb (2009) worked with Richard Ostfeld and Felicia Keesing on the possible role of invasive plant species in the ecology of Lyme disease, providing groundwork for future research.
  • Ana Elisa Perez-Quintero (2010) worked with Alan Berkowitz to explore how people view and understand non-native species, developing novel interview protocols.

Our innovative approaches to education are shared with the field at REU PI meetings, conferences, workshops and seminars. The Forum on Opportunities in Ecology brings undergrads together with a diverse group of professionals (teachers, environmental lawyers and activists, consultants, managers, politicians, etc.). They explore career options and delve into the ways that ecology is framed, used and influenced by society. In the Sharing Science Program, REU students teach younger students from Poughkeepsie, getting a taste for education and giving the youngsters near-peer role models.
